feed.title: Beauty Buy or Beware: Nail Effects
feed.subtitle: Bored by regular nail polish? With spring just around the corner, we’re looking for fun ways to jazz up our nails – without an expensive salon manicure. This week, the Dose.ca team put OPI Shatter Lacquer and Sally Hansen’s Real Nail Polish Strips to the test.

content.div:
Bored by regular nail polish? With spring just around the corner, we’re looking for fun ways to jazz up our nails – without an expensive salon manicure. This week, the Dose.ca team put OPI Shatter Lacquer and Sally Hansen’s Real Nail Polish Strips to the test.



Sally Hansen Salon Effects Real Nail Polish Strips (suggested retail price: $9.95; available exclusively at Wal-Mart)

“It took me a while to master the application of this one. While putting stickers on your nails doesn’t sound particularly difficult, getting the decal lined up perfectly with my cuticles proved to be a challenge. After you apply the sticker, you simply fold what’s remaining over the edge of your nail and use an emery board to file off the excess. It’s pretty easy to smooth the sticker over your nail and avoid bubbles (though I found the corners a bit tricky). Applying it is definitely trickier than using nail polish, but the results seem to last much longer. I’ve been wearing the stickers for six days now, and there’s no sign of peeling yet. I even tried removing one with nail polish remover (as suggested) and it took a crazy amount of rubbing before it finally came off. The process is a little too intense to recommend for the solid-coloured stickers (just use regular polish instead), but there are some very cool striped and patterned designs that would make it worth it. Rating: 3/5” – Jen McDonnell, managing editor, Dose.ca

"When the Sally Hansen Salon Effects Real Nail Polish Strips arrived on my desk, I thought, "Stickers for your nails? What are we, 12?!” But it turns out they are not stickers; they’re actually thin sheets of nail polish. They're available in a variety of colours and patterns, making them a great option for any fashionista that wants the fancy salon design without the fancy salon price. Each box contains 16 long nail strips, but if you're crafty, you can cut each strip in half and squeeze out an extra application. If you do that, just be sure to tightly reseal the leftovers to keep the strips fresh. The application was a little tricky. I had a difficult time lining up the bottom of the stickers with my cuticles, but after I got the hang of it (and learned how to trim the edges with a file) I was in business. I would definitely try these again, but only for an intricate pattern. It just doesn't seem worth the price and the hassle for the single hued strips. Rating: 4/5" –Miranda Furtado, style editor, Dose.ca

“Peel and stick: there’s probably no easier method of zazzing up your nails with a unique design -- and not just because I have no clue how to paint intricate textures such as ‘60s mod florals and lacey damask patterns on my digits. (Those particular patterns being just two of the styles offered in this line.) Wacky patterns aside, I’ve never experienced a quicker way of giving myself a manicure. Applying polish is always followed by a waiting game. You know the one: that half hour or so where you live life as a quadriplegic for fear your manicure will smudge. Since there’s no drying involved with this product, when your nails are done, they’re done. And considering I managed to both get the hang of the technique (Jen does a nice job of explaining that above) and finish my manicure within 10 minutes, I’m tempted to keep a packet of these things around. Peel cellophane in case of emergency, last-minute gala, or some such.
Here some things I learned while applying them, which might be of use: Though it might be tricky to position the strips at first – especially considering the strips won’t identically match your nails unless your name is Sally Q. Hansen – I found they were durable enough to reposition if I needed a do-over. Just be gentle. (I tried the strips in the sparkly shade of Bling it On, so I can’t confirm this quality holds true for the other patterns.) And even if the strip doesn’t completely cover the shape of your nail – or if you manage to snag a strip during the application (which is probably even more likely) – don’t worry about cheating a little. Save the excess sticker that you rip away from each nail as you’re doing your manicure. I found that layering the strips was a quick and effective fix. Thanks to my strips’ glittery texture, I couldn’t even see where one piece ended and the other began.
One last thing about their durability: the other reviewers had way better luck with their manicures. I never experienced any chipping with the nail strips. Instead, the things just peeled off entirely -- and by day three, I was unintentionally rocking mismatched nails. As pretty as these polish strips are, they’re essentially just stickers – stickers which, over time, were prone to lifting on the corners and snagging my hair every time I brushed, touched and/or shampooed it. On the plus side, they come off cleanly – but $9.99 might be a little dear for something that might not survive half a week. Rating: 4/5” --Leah Collins, music editor, Dose.ca


OPI Shatter Lacquer (suggested retail price: $10.25; available at salons and select OPI retailers)

“We get so much stuff sent to our office that we’ve become pretty blasé about it, so it’s rare that a product is cool enough to have us all huddled around our style editor’s desk, “oohing” and “ahhing.” That was what happened the day Shatter landed. It’s nail polish (black or silver) that you use as a top coat over a regular polish. Shatter goes on much like a typical solid colour (albeit a really thick one), but it dries in pieces, letting the bottom shade peek through. I originally tried the black Shatter over bright red polish, but it looked too Halloween-y. I then tried it over light green polish, and the look transformed from gothy to a spring-like, cool crackle. It seemed to last a lot longer than regular nail polish, but that might just be because your nails look chipped to begin with, so you can’t really notice when it starts coming off. This is a very neat, very easy way to add a funky treatment to your nails. Rating: 5/5” – JM

"Can you say obsessed?! I've put OPI Shatter everywhere: my fingers, my toes – I even contemplated accessorizing my dog’s digits. I love this product because it can take any standard nail polish to a whole new level. (My personal favourite combination is to layer the black Shatter on top of the OPI’s Katy Perry light pink sparkle.) Shatter goes on really thick and it definitely took a bit of practice to get the right amount of coverage. When the polish starts to dry, that's when the cool factor kicks in. Within a few minutes, it starts to crackle and reveal the polish underneath. Based on awesomeness alone, I would love to rate this beauty find a 20 out of 10 (one for each perfectly polished finger and toe!), but since we’re stuck with a five-point scale, my rating is 5/5." -MF
